title: If the Nazis had not taken power in 1933 or that the Treaty of Versailles had not screwed Germany's economy, could the Weimar Republic survive to this day? - Quora

response.answer_text: Alex, Good question, actually during the later 20’s the German economy was growing at a nice rapid pace, and Hitler was losing votes at the poll. The concept of a democracy was very new and uncomfortable to most Germans because they were use to a monarchy. Well 1929 the collapse of the stock market made Hitler look real good because he somewhat predicted it would happen in Mein Kampf and his popularity started to rise again. If the market had not fallen and things went on smoothly around the world it’s possible the Weimar Republic could have survived, but also throw into the mix, Japan and their ambitions for a greater East Asian co prosperity sphere, wow the possibilities are endless. Who’s to say what could’ve been, but a good question .

While this question sounds academic, it is perhaps the most profound question now facing the world’s democracies. And the answer is no, Weimar almost certainly was doomed from the start. The reason? Republics require (small ’r’) republicans. Democracy requires (small ’d’) democrats. Weimar lacked the essential core of citizens willing to work defending relevant institutions. Absent that commitment, a republic withers and does.
